title: Protocol for in vitro phosphorylation of the MUS81-binding region of SLX4 using CDK1-cyclin B
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Examine target protein sequence properties and determine the number of expected phosphorylation sites
Timing: 1 h
The purpose of this step is to identify the number and position of CDK1 sites expected to be phosphorylated in the target protein sequence. The recognition motif for CDK1 is S/TP, where proline is an absolute requirement in the +1 position, and there is a preference for basic residues (lysine or arginine) at the +2 or +3 positions.15[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]
Using the target protein sequence, identify and record all of the expected CDK1 sites (S/TP).
Note: For example, the protein sequence for human SLX4MBR, consisting of residues 1528–1613, can be retrieved from the UniProt database[href=https://uniprot.org/] using the primary accession ID: Q8IY92. There are three TP sites located in the SLX4MBR (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). The target protein in this example (SLX4MBR) was purified from Escherichia coli and lacks phosphorylated residues.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Target proteins purified from other organisms, such as insect or mammalian cells, may include some phosphorylated residues.
Evaluate the physical and chemical properties of the target protein sequence using Expasy ProtParam[href=https://web.expasy.org/protparam]. Record the parameters described in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for the target protein.

The molar and mass extinction coefficients shown below are calculated assuming a 1 cm path length and that all pairs of Cys residues are reduced.
Note: Protein sequences lacking tryptophan residues, like SLX4MBR, can result in more than 10% error in the computed extinction coefficient.
Alternatives: If the protein sequence lacks both tryptophan and tyrosine residues, an alternative spectroscopic method for measuring protein concentration can be employed by using the absorbance at 215 nm (A215) and 225 nm (A225) (see troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]).
Dialysis and protein concentration determination
Timing: 18–24 h

Prior to dialysis, the target protein (e.g., SLX4MBR) should be purified to >95% purity, with approximately 1 mL at 100–300 μM. The target protein is then dialyzed into a buffer suitable for phosphorylation with CDK1-cyclin B. This step is especially important if the target protein is stored in a phosphate-based buffer, as phosphate can inhibit kinases16[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16] and may lead to the unwanted formation of insoluble magnesium phosphate salts. Notably, magnesium is an essential component to the phosphorylation reaction, acting as a cofactor to form the ATP:Mg2+ chelate. Before performing dialysis, users should select dialysis tubing with a molecular weight cutoff (MWCO) that is lower than the molecular weight of the target protein. For example, SLX4MBR is approximately 10 kDa, so 3.5 kDa MWCO dialysis tubing is used to retain the target protein within the dialysis tubing. After dialysis, the protein concentration is measured to determine the appropriate concentrations of ATP and CDK1-cyclin B to add for the phosphorylation reaction.
Hydrate the dialysis tubing.
Fill a 400 mL beaker with 300 mL of ddH2O.
Fill one Maxi GeBAFlex (3.5 kDa MWCO) dialysis tube with 3 mL of ddH2O.
Place the dialysis tubing in a floating rack and into the 300 mL of ddH2O.
Allow the dialysis tubing to hydrate for 5 min at room temperature.
Remove and empty the dialysis tubing.
Load the dialysis tubing with the target protein sample (e.g., SLX4MBR). Perform the following steps in a cold room:
Pipette 1 mL of SLX4MBR (400 μM or 2.5 mg/mL) into the dialysis tubing.
Place the dialysis tube in a floating rack and into 5 L of pre-cooled Protein Dialysis Buffer.
Add a clean stir bar to the 5 L of Protein Dialysis Buffer and move to a stir plate.

Add 2-mercaptoethanol to a final concentration of 1 mM into the Protein Dialysis Buffer.
Turn on the stir setting to allow gentle mixing of the dialysis solution.
Allow dialysis to occur for 18–24 h at 4°C.
Alternatives: The target protein can be prepared using other buffer exchange methods, such as a centrifugal protein concentrator or using an ÄKTA FPLC instrument equipped with a 5 mL HiTrap Desalting column (Cytiva). Although these methods are more costly than dialysis, one advantage is that they can often be completed in under 1 h.
After dialysis, remove the target protein sample (e.g., SLX4MBR) from the dialysis tubing.
Use a pipette to remove the SLX4MBR sample from the dialysis tubing and transfer into a 1.5 mL microfuge tube.
Record the approximate volume of SLX4MBR removed by pipetting.
Mix the SLX4MBR sample well using a pipette.
Store the sample on ice.
Note: Step 5 should be performed in a cold room or cold cabinet.
Determine the target protein concentration by absorbance spectroscopy.
Using a 10 mL syringe fitted with a 0.2 μm syringe filter, filter 10 mL of Protein Dialysis Buffer into a 15 mL conical tube.
Perform a blank measurement using the 0.2 μm filtered Protein Dialysis Buffer.
Measure the absorbance at 280 nm (   A 280   ) for the dialyzed SLX4MBR.

Protein phosphorylation using CDK1-cyclin B
Timing: 1–3 days
The purpose of this step is to perform in vitro phosphorylation of the target protein. Before proceeding with the phosphorylation reaction, consider the number of sites expected to be phosphorylated in the target protein sequence. For example, SLX4MBR contains three consensus sites for CDK1, with phosphorylation expected on T1544, T1561, and T1571 in full-length human SLX4 (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). Thus, 100 nmol of SLX4MBR will require 300 nmol of ATP to obtain stoichiometric phosphorylation of all three sites. In practice, the ATP concentration should be in molar excess to ensure that the phosphorylation reaction proceeds efficiently and to account for ATP hydrolysis, which decomposes into inorganic pyrophosphate and adenosine 5′-phosphate in alkaline solutions.17[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17]

In a 1.5 mL microfuge tube, mix only A components outlined in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]. Remove a 10 μL aliquot for SDS-PAGE analysis.

Note: A negative control sample (lacking CDK1-cyclin B) can be prepared in parallel to determine if the phosphorylation reaction conditions have an impact on protein stability or aggregation propensity.
Incubate at 30°C for 10 min.

Alternatives: CDK1-cyclin B has optimal activity at 30°C. However, if the target protein is unstable at 30°C, the phosphorylation reaction can be performed at 4°C for an extended amount of time.
Supplement the reaction mixture with an additional 1 mM ATP (i.e., an additional 10 μL of 100 mM ATP per 1 mL of sample).
Incubate at 4°C for 18–24 h in a ThermoMixer with gentle agitation (500 rpm).
After 24 h, monitor the reaction progress using 15% SDS-PAGE (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Figure 2. Monitoring phosphorylation of SLX4MBR by CDK1-cyclin B using SDS-PAGE

Incomplete phosphorylation can be detected as a band that migrates at the same apparent molecular weight as the negative control sample (i.e., SLX4MBR alone). Conversely, the phosphorylated product migrates at a higher apparent molecular weight. A total of 3 μg of each sample was loaded into a 15% SDS-PAGE gel before performing electrophoresis in 1× Tris-Glycine-SDS buffer at room temperature (150 V, 75 min). The SDS-PAGE gel was stained in InstantBlue and de-stained in water.
Note: If there is still a detectable quantity of non-phosphorylated material (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]), repeat steps 8–10 and allow the reaction to continue for an additional 24–48 h. Supplementing additional CDK1-cyclin B may also aid in bringing the reaction to completion.
Alternatives: If there is poor separation between the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated product(s) on denaturing SDS-PAGE, Phos-tag™ Acrylamide (Wako) may be used to improve resolution (see troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]).
Purification and analysis of the phosphorylated protein target
Timing: 4 h
After in vitro phosphorylation is complete, it is necessary to purify the phosphorylated target away from CDK1-cyclin B and reaction by-products. Size-exclusion chromatography is well-suited for this task, with the added benefits of removing protein aggregates and allowing for exchange into a buffer suitable for downstream analyses. Using a Superdex 75 Increase 10/300 GL column, CDK1-cyclin B (91 kDa) and protein aggregates elute in the void volume, while excess ATP and reaction by-products (such as ADP, AMP, and pyrophosphate) elute with the salt front (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A). This protocol has been used to reproducibly generate phosphorylated SLX4MBR using initial concentrations from 100 to 300 μM (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2529-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Purification of phosphorylated SLX4MBR using size-exclusion chromatography and a Superdex 75 Increase 10/300 GL column

(A) Phosphorylated SLX4MBR has an elution volume of 12 mL, whereas aggregates and CDK1-cyclinB elute in the void volume (approx. 7–8 mL), and reaction by-products elute in the salt front (approx. 18–22 mL).
(B) An overlay of four independent preparations of phosphorylated SLX4MBR using varying initial concentrations of SLX4MBR. The negative control (dotted black line) indicates non-phosphorylated SLX4MBR.
Following size-exclusion chromatography, SDS-PAGE is performed to screen fractions containing the phosphorylated protein, where selected fractions are pooled and concentrated using a centrifugal concentrator. Lastly, the sample needs to be analyzed by mass spectrometry. Intact mass spectrometry can be used to determine phosphorylation stoichiometry, and an SDS-PAGE gel slice can be used for tandem mass spectrometry to identify phosphorylated residues.
Connect a Superdex 75 Increase 10/300 GL column to an ÄKTA Pure FPLC, according to the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://cdn.cytivalifesciences.com/api/public/content/digi-16308-original]. Load four clean 96-deep well cassettes into the fraction collector.
Equilibrate the FPLC and chromatography column with Gel Filtration Buffer, according to the manufacturer’s instructions[href=https://cdn.cytivalifesciences.com/api/public/content/digi-16308-original].
Prepare the injection valve as follows:
Attach a 500 μL sample loop.
Attach a luer lock ferrule to the injection port of the injection valve.
Fill a 10 mL syringe with Gel Filtration Buffer. Remove any bubbles or excess air.
Attach the 10 mL syringe to the injection port.
Equilibrate the 500 μL loop using 9 mL of Gel Filtration Buffer.
Critical: Do not remove the syringe, which contains excess buffer.
Using the Method Editor software from Unicorn, create the following method:
Block 1: Method Settings.
Under Column selection, set the “Column type” to Superdex 75 Increase 10/300 GL. Use the default pre-column and delta-column pressure limits.
Under Column position, select the position where the column is attached.
Under Flow rate, set this value to 0.500 mL/min. Uncheck the box for “Control the flow to avoid overpressure”.

Under Unit selection, set the “Method Base Unit” to “CV” (or column volumes) and set the “Flow Rate Unit” to “mL/min”.
If the FPLC is equipped with a variable wavelength detector, select Monitor Settings and set the wavelengths (in nm) to UV1 = 280, UV2 = 260, and UV3 = 214. Check the boxes for UV2 and UV3 wavelengths.
Block 2: Sample Application.
Check the box for “Use the same flow rate as in Method Settings”.
Select the option “Inject sample from loop”.
Fill loop using: Manual load.
Loop type: Capillary loop.
Empty loop with: 0.60 mL.
Under Fractionate, select: “in waste (do not collect)”.
Block 3: Elution.
Check the box for “Use the same flow rate as in Method Settings”.
Select the option “Isocratic elution”. Set the Volume: 1.0 CV.
Under Fractionate, select: “using fraction collector”.
Check the box “Start fractionation after” and set the volume to 0.20 CV.
Under Fractionation settings, set the Fractionation type to “Fixed Volume fractionation”, set the Fractionation destination to “96 deep well plate” and set the Fixed fractionation volume to 0.20 mL.
Block 4: Equilibration.
Uncheck the box for “Reset UV monitor”.
Check the box for “Use the same flow rate as in Method Settings”.
Under Equilibrate until, select the option “the total volume is” and set the volume to 0.5 CV.
Save the method as “Gel Filtration Method” (or similar).
Prepare the phosphorylation reaction mixture for injection as follows:
Centrifuge for 10 min at 21,000 × g (4°C) in a pre-cooled microcentrifuge.
Prepare a 1 mL syringe with a clean needle.
Slowly load the phosphorylation reaction mixture into the syringe. Avoid bubbles.
Draw back the syringe to create an air gap at the top of the syringe. Slowly expel the air until the protein solution beads on the surface of the syringe.

Inject the phosphorylation reaction mixture into the 500 μL loop as follows:
Using the System Control software from Unicorn, set the injection valve position from “Manual Load” to “Inject”.
Attach the syringe to the injection port.
Set the injection valve position from “Inject” to “Manual Load”.
Slowly inject 500 μL of the phosphorylation reaction mixture into the sample loop, using the graduations on the 1 mL syringe as a guide.
Critical: Do not remove the syringe after injecting the sample.
Using the System Control software, open the “Gel Filtration Method” created in step 3 and start the method.
After the method is complete, inject the remaining contents of the 1 mL syringe into the 500 μL loop. After the 500 μL loop is loaded, repeat step 6.
Critical: Do not remove the syringe after injecting the sample.
Note: Aggregated proteins and unfolded polypeptides will elute from the column in the void volume. This material should not be collected for downstream processing (see troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]).
Screen fractions of the phosphorylated target protein by SDS-PAGE (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).

Figure 4. SDS-PAGE analysis of phosphorylated SLX4MBR purified by size-exclusion chromatography
Phosphorylated SLX4MBR migrates slower than non-phosphorylated SLX4MBR. The SDS-PAGE gel (15%) was stained with InstantBlue and de-stained in water.
Pool peak fractions containing the phosphorylated target protein and concentrate using an Ultra-4 3 kDa MWCO centrifugal concentrator, following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Note: The MWCO of the centrifugal concentrator should be lower than the molecular weight of the target protein. For example, we used a 3 kDa MWCO because SLX4MBR is approximately 10 kDa.
Transfer the contents of the concentrator to a microfuge tube. Estimate the volume by pipetting and measure the protein concentration by absorbance spectroscopy.
